correction_response: This tweet is misinformed. The Bible does contain pronouns, including those referring to God. For instance, the 2011 translation of the New International Version Bible refers to God as "He" and "the Father" (https://www.nbcnews.com/id/wbna42138347). Moreover, the Bible uses both masculine and feminine language to describe God, as seen in Exodus 3 where God's name, Yahweh, combines both female and male grammatical endings (https://theconversation.com/what-the-early-church-thought-about-gods-gender-100077). The Bible also uses gender-neutral language in some translations (https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/06/southern-baptists-embrace-gender-inclusive-language-in-the-bible/529935/).
note_1_text: There are pronouns in the Bible, whether you read it in English, Hebrew, or Greek. You can check out Strong's Concordance to look up every time a given word appears in the Bible.    For example, here's a list of every single time the Hebrew word for "he" is used in the Bible.    https://biblehub.com/hebrew/1931.htm
note_2_text: A pronoun is a word that refers to a noun, including he/she/they/it/them. For example, the first verse in Esther says “and it was in the day of Ahauserus — he is Ahauserus”
